avalancheActivity.comment:
The fresh snow of last week and very particularly the sometimes deep wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant at intermediate and high altitudes. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack can indicate the danger, caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
As a consequence of the moderate northeasterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form on Sunday, in particular along the border between Valais and Italy, along the border with France.
As a consequence of solar radiation more small and medium-sized natural dry avalanches are possible. In some places avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.

snowpackStructure.comment:
30 to 50 cm of snow, and up to 60 cm in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2200 m, in particular along the border with France. Up to 2200 m rain has fallen. The westerly wind has transported the new snow significantly. These weather conditions on Friday gave rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack in some places in particular along the border with France below approximately 2500 m. Naturally triggered avalanches and reports filed by observers have confirmed this situation.
The weather conditions caused a strengthening of the near-surface layers on Saturday.
The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations. In all aspects snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2000 m, depending on the infuence of the wind.

tendency.highlights: The weather will be cold. The wind will be moderate to strong. The avalanche danger will persist.

avalancheActivity.comment:
As a consequence of the moderate wind the wind slabs will increase in size. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released, especially at their margins. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and on extremely steep slopes. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses.
As a consequence of solar radiation more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized dry avalanches are possible, in particular at the base of rock walls, and in extremely steep terrain.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Backcountry touring calls for restraint.

snowpackStructure.comment:
20 to 40 cm of snow has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. The northwesterly wind has transported the new snow.
The weather conditions on Thursday gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2200 m.

In all aspects snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2000 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low and intermediate altitudes less snow than usual is lying.

tendency.highlights: Slight decrease in avalanche danger as a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation.

avalancheActivity.comment: The sometimes storm force wind has transported only a little snow. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes mostly shallow wind slabs formed. Caution is to be exercised on extremely steep slopes, especially at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example, in particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 2 (moderate). In these regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in extremely steep terrain at intermediate and high altitudes.

regions.name: B - VALLI DI GRESSONEY, AYAS, CHAMPORCHER

snowpackStructure.comment:
5 to 15 cm of snow has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 1800 m.
The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations. In all aspects snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2200 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. On steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m a little snow is lying. At low and intermediate altitudes from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
